title: Command of Evidence
subtitle: Finding & Using Textual Support
learning_objectives: The Core: Master locating and evaluating textual evidence
The Skill: Distinguish strong evidence from weak support
The Problem: Multiple quotes may seem relevant—choose the one that directly proves the claim
Key Strategy: The 3-Phase PROVE Strategy for 100% provable evidence choices

content.heading: The Main Quest
bullet_points: Decode what makes evidence strong vs. weak
Eliminate evidence that's related but doesn't prove

content.heading: PHASE 1: Understand the Claim
content.subtitle: What Exactly Needs to Be Proven?

core_principle.title: The Precision Principle
core_principle.description: Evidence questions test whether you can identify what DIRECTLY supports a specific claim. Related information isn't enough—evidence must prove the exact point being made.

strategy_steps.title: Read the Claim Carefully
strategy_steps.description: Identify exactly what needs to be proven

examples.what_needs_proof: Specific connection between gardens and crime reduction
examples.not_enough: Urban gardens exist, Gardens are popular, Crime is a problem

examples.claim: Renewable energy is becoming more affordable
examples.what_needs_proof: Evidence showing cost decreasing over time
examples.not_enough: Renewable energy exists, It's environmentally friendly, Some people use it

strategy_steps.title: Identify Key Terms
strategy_steps.description: Break down the claim into components that need support

example.claim: Social media use correlates with increased anxiety in teenagers

key_terms.teenagers: Must involve this age group specifically

example.what_proves_it: Evidence showing link between teens' social media use and higher anxiety levels

strategy_steps.title: Anticipate What Would Prove It
strategy_steps.description: Before looking at options, predict what type of evidence would work
prediction_categories: Specific examples (concrete instances demonstrating the point)

analysis.what_needs_proof: Connection between exercise and mental health improvement
analysis.strong_evidence: Studies show 30 minutes of daily exercise reduces anxiety by 25%
analysis.why_strong: Quantifies exercise (30 min), specifies mental health aspect (anxiety), shows improvement (reduces by 25%)
analysis.weak_evidence: Many people feel better after working out
analysis.why_weak: Vague ('many people,' 'feel better'), no specific mental health measure, no quantification

core_principle.title: Specificity Beats Generality
core_principle.description: Stronger evidence is more specific, measurable, and directly relevant. The SAT rewards choosing the most concrete, precise support.

evidence_hierarchy.definition: Numbers, percentages, measurements that prove the claim
examples: 40% reduction in crime rates after gardens established
Participants showed 30% improvement in test scores
Research shows bioluminescence evolved independently 40 times
Studies link 3+ hours social media to higher depression risk
Experiments demonstrate vertical farms use 95% less water
evidence_hierarchy.why_strong: Based on systematic evidence gathering, credible methodology

evidence_hierarchy.definition: Statements from credible sources with relevant expertise
examples: Neuroscientists confirm facial recognition occurs in fusiform area
Economists argue that renewable energy costs will continue falling
evidence_hierarchy.why_moderate: Relies on authority's credibility, but still valuable support

examples: Paris implemented 15-minute city concept with positive results
Marie Curie won Nobel Prizes in two different fields
evidence_hierarchy.why_moderate_weak: Shows it's possible but doesn't prove general pattern

examples: Many people believe exercise helps mental health
Urban gardens are popular in cities
Some researchers think social media affects teens
evidence_hierarchy.why_weak: No concrete evidence, uses hedging language (many, some, popular)

questions.question: Does it address the EXACT claim?
questions.example: Claim: 'Gardens reduce crime' → Evidence must mention BOTH gardens AND crime

common_traps.description: Evidence discusses the topic but doesn't prove the specific claim

example.claim: Vertical farming solves food security challenges
example.trap_evidence: Vertical farms use advanced LED lighting systems
example.why_trap: About vertical farming but doesn't address food security

common_traps.description: Provides context but doesn't support the claim

example.trap_evidence: Bioluminescence is found in many marine organisms

common_traps.description: Shows relationship but claim requires causal link

example.trap_evidence: People who exercise report better mood
example.why_trap: Shows correlation, not causation (maybe happier people exercise more)

elements.reveal: SAT evidence questions test precision. Evidence that's 'kind of related' or 'partially supportive' is wrong. Only direct, specific proof is correct.

content.heading: PHASE 3: Eliminate Weak Evidence
content.subtitle: The 100% Rule: Find Why 3 Are Wrong, Prove 1 Is Right

elimination_process.title: Check for DIRECT support
elimination_process.action: Eliminate any evidence that doesn't address all key terms in the claim

example.eliminate: Evidence only mentioning gardens (not crime) or only crime (not gardens)

elimination_process.title: Reject VAGUE statements
elimination_process.action: Eliminate evidence with hedging language or no specifics
elimination_process.example: Eliminate: 'Many people feel gardens improve neighborhoods' (too vague)

elimination_process.title: Remove BACKGROUND info
elimination_process.action: Eliminate evidence providing context rather than proof

example.eliminate: Flow state was discovered in the 1970s (background, not proof of improvement)

elimination_process.title: Verify STRONGEST remains
elimination_process.action: Among remaining options, choose most specific and measurable
tiebreaker_rules: Direct quotes > paraphrases (when both prove claim equally)

worked_elimination.claim: Renewable energy adoption is driven by economic factors

options.text: Solar panel costs have dropped 85% since 2010
options.evaluation: ✓ Specific economic data (cost reduction), directly proves economic factor driving adoption

options.text: Wind energy now provides 8% of total US electricity
options.evaluation: ✗ Shows adoption occurring but doesn't prove economic factors drive it

options.text: Government incentives include tax credits up to $7,500
options.evaluation: ✓ Economic factor BUT less direct than option A (incentive vs. inherent cost drop)
✗ Environmental factor, not economic—doesn't match claim

worked_elimination.reasoning: Most direct economic evidence with specific quantification

slides.title: Guided Practice: The Strategy in Action

content.heading: Let's Apply All 3 Phases Together
content.passage: Recent studies indicate that urban gardens significantly benefit local communities. Dr. Sarah Chen's research in Detroit found that neighborhoods with community gardens saw a 40% reduction in crime rates. Additionally, these gardens provide fresh produce to families, with 78% of participating households reporting improved nutrition. The social aspect is equally important, as residents form lasting friendships through shared gardening activities.
content.claim: Urban gardens provide multiple benefits to communities
content.question: Which sentence best supports this claim?

walkthrough.question: What does the claim require?
walkthrough.answer: Evidence showing gardens provide MULTIPLE benefits (not just one)
walkthrough.reasoning: Key term: 'multiple benefits'—need evidence showing variety of positive effects

walkthrough.question: Which evidence pieces exist in the passage?
walkthrough.answer: 40% crime reduction, 78% nutrition improvement, social friendships
walkthrough.reasoning: Three distinct benefits mentioned with varying levels of specificity

walkthrough.question: Evaluate each option

options_analysis.text: Neighborhoods with community gardens saw a 40% reduction in crime rates
options_analysis.analysis: ✓ Strong specific data BUT only shows ONE benefit (crime reduction), claim needs MULTIPLE

options_analysis.text: 78% of participating households reported improved nutrition
options_analysis.analysis: ✓ Strong specific data BUT only shows ONE benefit (nutrition), claim needs MULTIPLE

options_analysis.text: Dr. Sarah Chen conducted research in Detroit
options_analysis.analysis: ✗ Background information, doesn't prove any benefits at all

options_analysis.text: Residents form lasting friendships through shared gardening activities
options_analysis.analysis: ✓ Shows ONE benefit (social) BUT not quantified and doesn't show MULTIPLE

walkthrough.correct_answer: None of the individual sentences prove 'multiple benefits'—would need combination
walkthrough.teaching_point: This reveals key insight: Sometimes you need to look for evidence that EXPLICITLY states multiple benefits, or that COMBINES information

walkthrough.question: If we had to choose the BEST available evidence?
walkthrough.answer: Option A or B (both provide strongest quantitative evidence for individual benefits)
walkthrough.reasoning: When 'multiple benefits' claim can't be proven by single quote, choose the strongest single piece of evidence—quantitative data wins

slides.title: Your Turn: Apply the PROVE Strategy

content.heading: Independent Practice
content.instructions: Use all 3 phases: Understand Claim → Evaluate Evidence → Eliminate Weak Support
content.passage: Renewable energy adoption has accelerated dramatically in recent years. Solar panel costs have dropped 85% since 2010, making installation affordable for average homeowners. Wind energy now provides 8% of total US electricity generation, up from just 1% in 2000. Government incentives, including tax credits up to $7,500 for solar installations, have further encouraged adoption. Energy companies report that renewable sources now compete directly with fossil fuels on price.
content.claim: Economic factors are driving renewable energy adoption
content.question: Which sentence provides the strongest evidence for this claim?
content.strategy_reminder: Phase 1: What exactly needs proof? (Economic factors driving adoption) Phase 2: Which evidence is most specific and direct? Phase 3: Eliminate vague, unrelated, or background info.

options: Solar panel costs have dropped 85% since 2010
Wind energy now provides 8% of total US electricity
Government incentives include tax credits up to $7,500
Renewable sources now compete directly with fossil fuels on price
content.explanation:
Let's apply the 3 phases:

PHASE 1—Claim analysis:
Key terms: 'Economic factors' + 'driving adoption'
Needs: Evidence showing financial/cost reasons causing people to adopt renewables

PHASE 2—Evidence evaluation:
A: 85% cost drop = direct economic factor with specific quantification ✓
B: 8% electricity provision = shows adoption happened, NOT what drives it
C: Tax credits = economic factor BUT government incentive (secondary factor)
D: Price competition = economic factor BUT less specific than A's quantification

PHASE 3—Elimination:
B: ✗ Shows result (adoption level), not cause (economic driver)
C: ✗ Economic but secondary—incentive added to make already-improving economics better
D: ✗ States conclusion but less concrete than A—'compete' is vague vs. '85% drop'
A: ✓ STRONGEST—Specific quantitative data (85%) showing fundamental economic change (cost drop) that directly enables adoption

A wins because: most specific (85%), most direct economic cause (cost drop enables affordability), and strongest proof of economic driver.

content.heading: Master These Criteria—Choose Perfect Evidence Every Time

rows: When available, almost always correct answer
Studies show X, Research reveals Y
When no data or research findings available
Paris implemented X with results Y
Illustrates possibility but doesn't prove pattern
Many people believe, Some think, Popular
X was discovered in 1970s, X exists

content.expert_insight: The SAT rewards precision. Evidence must directly address every key term in the claim with specific, measurable support. 'Kind of related' equals wrong.

content.heading: Command of Evidence Mastery
key_points: Phase 1: Understand exactly what the claim requires—identify all key terms that need support
Phase 2: Evaluate evidence strength—quantitative data strongest, vague statements weakest
Phase 3: Eliminate evidence that's related but doesn't directly prove the specific claim
The 100% Rule: Evidence must address ALL key terms in claim with specific, measurable support
content.strategy_reminder: Remember PROVE: Pin down claim requirements, Rank evidence by strength, Observe which directly supports, Verify specificity, Eliminate weak/indirect options
content.expert_insight: Three common traps: (1) Related but not direct, (2) Background instead of proof, (3) Shows one aspect when claim requires multiple. Always check if evidence proves the EXACT claim.

slides.title: Mastery Check
slides.question:
Passage discusses meditation and stress in students. Claim: 'Meditation reduces stress in students.' Which would be the STRONGEST evidence?

A) Students often feel calmer after meditating
B) Meditation has been practiced for thousands of years
C) A study of 200 students found 15-minute daily meditation reduced cortisol levels by 30%
D) Many teachers recommend meditation for stress relief
options: Students often feel calmer after meditating
Meditation has been practiced for thousands of years
A study of 200 students found 15-minute daily meditation reduced cortisol levels by 30%
Many teachers recommend meditation for stress relief
slides.explanation:
Phase analysis:

PHASE 1—Claim requirements:
Key terms: 'Meditation' + 'reduces stress' + 'in students'
Needs: Evidence showing meditation causes measurable stress reduction specifically in students

PHASE 2—Evidence evaluation:
A: Vague ('often feel calmer')—no measurement, no proof of causation
B: Background information—historical practice doesn't prove stress reduction
C: ✓ Quantitative research data (200 students, 30% reduction) with biological stress measure (cortisol)
D: Opinion/recommendation—doesn't prove it actually works

PHASE 3—Elimination:
A: ✗ WEAK—'often' and 'feel' are not specific or measurable
B: ✗ NOT EVIDENCE—historical background, irrelevant to stress reduction
C: ✓ STRONGEST—Specific study (200 students), measurable outcome (30% cortisol drop), addresses all key terms
D: ✗ MODERATE-WEAK—Opinion, not proof; 'recommend' doesn't prove effectiveness

C wins: Most specific (200 students, 15 minutes, 30%), most direct (cortisol = stress biomarker), strongest evidence type (research with quantitative results)

strategy_card.title: The PROVE Strategy Quick Reference

steps: Read claim carefully—what exactly needs proof?
Predict what type of evidence would prove it
Rank by hierarchy: Quantitative > Research > Expert > Examples > General
Check if evidence is SPECIFIC and MEASURABLE
Verify evidence addresses ALL key terms in claim
Remove evidence not addressing all key terms
Remove background info that doesn't prove claim
Choose most specific, quantitative option remaining

strategy_card.the_100_rule: Evidence must directly address every key term in the claim. Related-but-not-direct equals wrong. Quantitative data almost always wins.

common_mistakes: Choosing evidence related to topic but not proving specific claim
Selecting background information instead of direct proof
Picking vague statements over quantitative data
Missing that claim requires multiple aspects, choosing evidence showing only one

evidence_quick_reference.Strongest: Quantitative data with specifics (85% drop, 40% reduction)
evidence_quick_reference.Weak: General statements with hedging (many, some, often)
evidence_quick_reference.Not Evidence: Background info, historical context, existence statements

strategy_integration.key_innovation: 3-Phase PROVE Strategy: Understand Claim → Evaluate Strength → Eliminate Weak
